pull_request.title: hipsycl: restrict compatibility with llvm for v0.8.0
pull_request.body: In an environment where I had llvm 15 ([released in 2022](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-15.0.0)), I was getting compilation errors because hipSYCL v0.8.0 ([released in 2019](https://github.com/AdaptiveCpp/AdaptiveCpp/releases/tag/v0.8.0)) couldn't find functions that had been removed in newer versions of LLVM.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -6804,25 +6804,58 @@ the adapter role is to "emulate" a method resolution order like the one represen
 Specifying License Information
 ------------------------------
 
-A significant portion of software that Spack packages is open source. Most open
-source software is released under one or more common open source licenses.
-Specifying the specific license that a package is released under in a project's
-`package.py` is good practice. To specify a license, find the SPDX identifier for
-a project and then add it using the license directive:
+Most of the software in Spack is open source, and most open source software is released
+under one or more `common open source licenses <https://opensource.org/licenses/>`_.
+Specifying the license that a package is released under in a project's
+`package.py` is good practice. To specify a license, find the `SPDX identifier
+<https://spdx.org/licenses/>`_ for a project and then add it using the license
+directive:
 
 .. code-block:: python
 
    license("<SPDX Identifier HERE>")
 
+For example, the SPDX ID for the Apache Software License, version 2.0 is ``Apache-2.0``,
+so you'd write:
+
+.. code-block:: python
+
+   license("Apache-2.0")
+
+Or, for a dual-licensed package like Spack, you would use an `SPDX Expression
+<https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2-draft/SPDX-license-expressions/>`_ with both of its
+licenses:
+
+.. code-block:: python
+
+   license("Apache-2.0 OR MIT")
+
 Note that specifying a license without a when clause makes it apply to all
 versions and variants of the package, which might not actually be the case.
 For example, a project might have switched licenses at some point or have
 certain build configurations that include files that are licensed differently.
-To account for this, you can specify when licenses should be applied. For
-example, to specify that a specific license identifier should only apply
-to versionup to and including 1.5, you could write the following directive:
+Spack itself used to be under the ``LGPL-2.1`` license, until it was relicensed
+in version ``0.12`` in 2018.
+
+You can specify when a ``license()`` directive applies using with a ``when=``
+clause, just like other directives. For example, to specify that a specific
+license identifier should only apply to versions up to ``0.11``, but another
+license should apply for later veresions, you could write:

pull_request.title: docs: update `license()` docs with examples and links
pull_request.body:
- [x] Add links to information people are going to want to know when adding license information to their packages (namely OSI licenses and SPDX identifiers).
- [x] Update the packaging docs for `license()` with Spack as an example for `when=`. After all, it's a dual-licensed package that changed once in the past.
- [x] Add link to https://spdx.org/licenses/ in the `spack create` boilerplate as well.

commits.message:
docs: update `license()` docs with examples and links

- [x] Add links to information people are going to want to know when adding license
      information to their packages (namely OSI licenses and SPDX identifiers).
- [x] Update the packaging docs for `license()` with Spack as an example for `when=`.
      After all, it's a dual-licensed package that changed once in the past.
- [x] Add link to https://spdx.org/licenses/ in the `spack create` boilerplate as well.

issue.title: py-numpy: add v1.26

labels.name: stand-alone-tests
labels.description: Stand-alone (or smoke) tests for installed packages

issue.body:
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/releases/tag/v1.26.0

@rgommers congrats on the successful port to meson! I see matplotlib is planning to follow suit next.

You'll have to help me with the BLAS/LAPACK flags. Is it possible to pass flags through pip now or do we need to use the same hack as we did for scipy?

Successfully builds on macOS 13.5.2 (Apple M2 Pro) with Python 3.10.10 and Apple Clang 14.0.3.

### 1.25.2 (distutils-based)

37.82s to build

### 1.26.0 (meson-based)

23.19s to build

comment.body:
> @rgommers any idea when support for this version of Xcode/clang/macOS/whatever was added?

It looks like that `isnan` build error was fixed in `1.10.0`. No sure there are no other issues in 1.10.0 though, since XCode 14 is pretty new, but it will likely work.

> Also, any other build deps you think we can relax the upper bounds on? That may make it easier to concretizer newer versions.

IIRC the `meson-python` and `pythran` upper bounds can safely be removed, while there was one issue with `pybind11` around 2.10.4/2.11, so that may best be left untouched.

comment.body:
New scipy failure:
```
  In file included from scipy/spatial/_ckdtree.cxx:1007:
  /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/c++/v1/complex:1401:53: error: expected unqualified-id
      if (__x.real() == 0 && (__x.imag() == 0 || std::isnan(__x.imag())))
                                                      ^
  /private/var/folders/pc/qn0ft6pn27j3l3zn1kqm30y80000gv/T/gitlab-runner-1/spack-stage/spack-stage-py-scipy-1.8.1-mqtcvnbw75fvk64oy7vik5l7gped6kes/spack-src/scipy/_lib/_c99compat.h:124:30: note: expanded from macro 'isnan'
              #define isnan(x) ((x) != (x))                
                               ^
  1 warning and 1 error generated.
```
@rgommers any idea when support for this version of Xcode/clang/macOS/whatever was added?

Also, any other build deps you think we can relax the upper bounds on? That may make it easier to concretizer newer versions.

pull_request.title: conquest: add build system changes and library paths
pull_request.body:
There's been a change in development to where files included by the makefile are kept and how they are included. This PR fixes the spack package to use them in future versions.

I also discovered on another system I was building on that I had to add the `ld_flags` of `fftw` and `libxc` (in addition to `blas` and `scalapack`) to the Makefile to link them.

Apologies, I added another thing :blush: Inputs for some common benchmarks are installed above version 1.2

comment.body:
In pyproject.toml of py-cleo-0.8.1:
```
[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core>=1.0.0a5"]
```

In pyproject.toml of py-cleo-1.0.0 and py-cleo-2.0.0:
```
[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core~=1.1.0"]
```
Which exclude poetry-core@2

In pyproject.toml of py-cleo-2.0.1:
```
[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core>=1.1.0"]
```

issue.title: py-numpy: add v1.26

labels.name: stand-alone-tests
labels.description: Stand-alone (or smoke) tests for installed packages

issue.body:
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/releases/tag/v1.26.0

@rgommers congrats on the successful port to meson! I see matplotlib is planning to follow suit next.

You'll have to help me with the BLAS/LAPACK flags. Is it possible to pass flags through pip now or do we need to use the same hack as we did for scipy?

Successfully builds on macOS 13.5.2 (Apple M2 Pro) with Python 3.10.10 and Apple Clang 14.0.3.

### 1.25.2 (distutils-based)

37.82s to build

### 1.26.0 (meson-based)

23.19s to build

comment.body:
This bumped macOS to scipy 1.8.1 but now there's a new issue that proves that Spack's concretizer is too smart for its own good. Scipy 1.8.1 requires pythran 0.10, which doesn't support Apple Clang 13+ (#30734). So Spack decides to build everything with Apple Clang 15 except Pythran, which it builds with GCC. This then fails when Apple Clang 15 tries to link Scipy to Pythran.

Some possible solutions:

1. Add Apple Clang 13+ conflict to scipy 1.8 (I don't like this)
2. Relax the upper bounds on the Pythran dep version (quickest fix but doesn't really solve the concretizer bug)
3. Remove GCC from the macOS CI compiler list (don't know how to do, but would help debug builds)
4. Add a mechanism to declare a conflict not only for a package but those that depend on it as well (hardest to do but most technically correct)

Curious if @eugeneswalker has thoughts on 3 or @alalazo has thoughts on 4. I'll try 2 for now to get the tests passing. This might even let us build newer versions of scipy in CI.

issue.title: Spack cleans up after itself in the active shell
issue.body:
### Summary

Spack should make it so users can switch spack instances even when they have shell support enabled. 

### Rationale

Shell support for spack is wonderful but populates and manipulates the shell environment a lot. This makes it difficult to use multiple instances of spack cleanly. 

### Description

Requesting that sourcing a spack setup scripts first cleans up/unsets any old spack shell manipulations. 

A second related request would be a ‘spack goodbye’ command that uses can call to drop shell support for an active shell. Akin to typing ‘exit’ in the shell but just for spack features. 

### Additional information

_No response_

### General information

- [X] I have searched the issues of this repo and believe this is not a duplicate

commits.message:
gromacs: default to external blas & lapack (#40490)

* gromacs: default to external blas & lapack

* drop vendored lapack/blas altogether

pull_request.title: gromacs: default to external blas & lapack
pull_request.body:
If I understand correctly, `spack install gromacs` uses reference blas/lapack,
which sounds like a really bad idea:

1. bad performance by default
2. shadowing other package's blas/lapack

In fact, maybe best to just remove this altogether, given the list of conflicts
and the fact that Spack has reference blas and lapack as separate packages.

A user reported a 2x perf improvement by using intel's fftw, which is due to
the side effect of `gromacs` using MKL blas and lapack I think... How about
2x performance by default?

comment.body: I'll force merge this since it de-duplicates the cce compiler. (@kwryankrattiger  / @scottwittenburg)

What compiler fails with this? I suppose someone added this because superlu-dist doesn't set a C standard themselves, so it uses the compiler default, which is too old?

For `putenv` see https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/putenv.3.html, they should add a missing define. Maybe contribute that upstream?

pull_request.title: Fixes and options for package spglib
pull_request.body:
The cmake option to enable openmp support since v2.1.0 is SPGLIB_USE_OMP.
Added option to build the fortran interface, although usually just installing the source header is sufficient.

review.body:
LGTM.

I'm a bit concerned about the sudden removal of variants, but I see there is currently no solution in place: https://github.com/spack/spack/issues/38829.

--- 

For [reference](https://gitlab.com/gromacs/gromacs/-/blob/main/docs/dev-manual/build-system.rst?plain=1#L250-255):
```
.. cmake:: GMX_EXTERNAL_BLAS

   If not set (the default), CMake will first try to use an external BLAS library,
   and, if unsuccessful, fall back to using the one bundled with |Gromacs|.
   If set to ``OFF``, CMake will use the bundled one immediately.
   If set to ``ON``, CMake will use the external one, and raise an error if it is not found.
```
